newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Tensions rise in Moslem village on Serb land - UN.
newsitem.headline: Tensions rise in Moslem village on Serb land - UN.

text.p: U.N. international police on Monday reported rising tension between Serb police and Moslem residents of a northeastern village in Bosnian Serb territory who have complained of insults and night-time explosions.

The pre-war Moslem residents of Dugi Dio reoccupied their village in September, sparking a standoff with Serb authorities which ended after both sides signed a refugee return procedure and Serb police were allowed to conduct patrols.
U.N. spokesman Alex Ivanko said villagers had complained about several explosions and a 10-minute shooting spree from a neighbouring village in Serb territory on January 3.
Serb police confirmed the report but claimed it happened on the Moslem-Croat side of the line.
"The situation is very tense," said Ivanko, citing a report from an international police patrol.

Moslem residents told a visiting patrol of the International Police Task Force (IPTF) that they had been insulted by Serb police patrolling the village on Sunday. The police denied the claim, Ivanko said.
"As a precautionary measure, IPTF and (NATO-led) Stabilisation Forces will increase their patrolling in the area in and around Dugi Dio," he said.
The IPTF patrol also spotted Moslem villagers gathering on Sunday inside Dugi Dio and on high ground around it, and looking towards the Serb police station.
"They said they wanted to strategically deploy as a protection against the Serb police," Ivanko said.
He said IPTF had no reports of casualties or damage as a result of the explosions and shooting.
